title: Ticket #7330: Add python chirp module to bindings
description: Now that #6907 is in, include (HT)Chirp as part of the packaged bindings.
remarks:
2019-Oct-18 11:27:10 by jpatton:
Perhaps we could add https://github.com/htcondor/htchirp as a git submodule and import HTChirp as htcondor.chirp? That way, users can still pip/conda install htchirp separately for small jobs that don't need the whole set of bindings, and the maintainer of the htchirp package (me, at the moment) has a single place to look for any updates.

(Yes, htcondor.chirp would most likely be available on any and all startds older than 8.9.5, but consider that users might be running a different version of Python than the system Python(s) and so could not access the system htcondor module.)

2019-Oct-18 14:17:04 by jpatton:
git submodule of the HTChirp repository (which includes all sorts of packaging information) inside the HTCondor source tree is not great because it requires a symlink (rip Windows) to get the actual code we care about into the right location. Three ways forward:

  1. Blast away the HTChirp repo. Makes providing a separate package difficult :(
  2. Move the code bits out of the HTChirp repo into HTCondor and add HTCondor as a submodule in the HTChirp repo.
  3. Create a third repo that only houses the code bits that can be and submodule this repo in both the HTChirp and HTCondor repos (thanks ToddM).
2020-Apr-10 07:46:37 by tim:
Bulk change of target version from v080906 to v080907 using ticket-target-mover.

2020-May-27 10:32:47 by karpel:
Something I've been experimenting with for htcondor-dags is to make it a "namespace package" (https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0420/). Perhaps we could do the same here?

With a namespace package, you can import htcondor.chirp even though chirp is not actually physically inside the htcondor module.

2020-Jun-24 08:44:15 by jpatton:
Since the HTChirp repo/package is 99% a single Python file (htchirp.py) and development should be relatively rare, I have opted to copy htchirp.py (and related __init__.py) under /bindings/python/htcondor/htchirp and then document it.

While this will require manually copying htchirp.py whenever development is done in its GitHub repo, the upshot is that users will not have to install the entire HTCondor python bindings in to each job that wants to use HTChirp, instead it also lives as its own lightweight package in PyPI and conda-forge.
